<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18660>

Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch

--- Comment #2 from Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) ---
"Fascinating" as KH would say ..

Note that the current (non patched) code is really very nicely self-explaining
in using the  `row(df) > col(df)` idiom.
I had added  `.row()` and `.col()` to R a while ago, to make such code slightly
faster.
It's too bad you're using commercial closed-source company owned chats for
developing and discussion free software.

Can you summarize the major improvement we get practically by making the code
less self-explainable and hence somewhat harder to maintain?
A factor of three on one platform in one extreme example is not enough of an
analysis to me.

text:
*[Bug 18616] TukeyHSD not functioning properly with nested designs*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18616>

--- Comment #6 from Flavio Bello Fialho (<mailto:bello.flavio@gmail.com|bello.flavio@gmail.com>) ---
The p-values reported by TukeyHSD when there are non-estimable means are WRONG!
Tukey's HSD test corrects p-values when the number of compared means is greater
than 2, in order to account for simultaneous multiple comparisons (when
comparing only 2 means, it is equivalent to a t-test). However, you cannot
compare something to nothing. The correction must be made based on the real
number of means being compared (non-existing means cannot be used, and any
comparison involving them always results in NA). If this number is artificially
inflated by including non-existant means in the count, p-values will be
incorrectly higher. That is why you see a reduction in the p-value when the
error is corrected.

On <https://www.stata.com/manuals13/rpwcompare.pdf> (pages 13-14), we can see
that, when there is no interest in testing one of the marginal means, the
p-value is reduced, because the number of means being compared is smaller.
Applying that to our case, one will never have interest in comparing anything
to a non-existing mean, which should not be considered in the count.

I believe a reasonable alternative is to inform the correct p-value, but warn
the user if there are empty cells in the grid, thus allowing the user to decide
whether TukeyHSD should be used or not:

    ## remove levels with no observations
    if (sum(n == 0) > 0) {
        warning(sum(n == 0), " empty combinations of factors were dropped")
        nms <- nms[!<http://is.na|is.na>(means)]
        means <- means[!<http://is.na|is.na>(means)]
        n <- n[n > 0]
    }

Would that be proper default behavior?

elements.text: [Bug 18616] TukeyHSD not functioning properly with nested designs

) ---
The p-values reported by TukeyHSD when there are non-estimable means are WRONG!
Tukey's HSD test corrects p-values when the number of compared means is greater
than 2, in order to account for simultaneous multiple comparisons (when
comparing only 2 means, it is equivalent to a t-test). However, you cannot
compare something to nothing. The correction must be made based on the real
number of means being compared (non-existing means cannot be used, and any
comparison involving them always results in NA). If this number is artificially
inflated by including non-existant means in the count, p-values will be
incorrectly higher. That is why you see a reduction in the p-value when the
error is corrected.

On

(pages 13-14), we can see
that, when there is no interest in testing one of the marginal means, the
p-value is reduced, because the number of means being compared is smaller.
Applying that to our case, one will never have interest in comparing anything
to a non-existing mean, which should not be considered in the count.

I believe a reasonable alternative is to inform the correct p-value, but warn
the user if there are empty cells in the grid, thus allowing the user to decide
whether TukeyHSD should be used or not:

    ## remove levels with no observations
    if (sum(n == 0) > 0) {
        warning(sum(n == 0), " empty combinations of factors were dropped")
        nms <- nms[!

(means)]
        n <- n[n > 0]
    }

Would that be proper default behavior?

text:
*[Bug 18660] as.matrix.dist performance*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18660>

--- Comment #4 from Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) ---
(In reply to Martin Maechler from comment #2)
I did an analysis myself; also I was exaggerating a bit;  the new code *is* not
as self-explaining as the original one.
OTOH, it's been a nice exercise to work to improve its R efficieny, and I do
believe this should be honored.

Also, BTW, I did like the use `%||%` in Tim's original patch. .. after a bit
more "compacting" the Heather's code, I've analyzed its empirical complexity
myself 
-- and the usual  log-log plot does show that indeed, the improvements do
happen also for small n, but you need to measure a bit more carefully to
notice.
Here's some nice base R - only code for the analysis and I will attach the
plot, too.
```
## parametrized in  {n,p}
do1 <- function(n1, p=2) {
    di <- dist(matrix(runif(n1*p), ncol = p))
    if(n1 <= 200) { ## too fast for just one as.matrix() -->  do k times
        ik <- seq_len( k <- floor((400/n1)^1.5) )
        system.time(for(i in ik) m <- as.matrix(di)) / k
    } else
        system.time(m <- as.matrix(di))
}
if(dir.exists(myD <- "..../MISC/Speed")) # for saved results
    setwd(myD)

(n.s <- sort(outer(c(1,2,5), 10^(1:4)))[1:6]) # 10 20 ... 500 -- be fast for
checking
(n.s <- sort(outer(c(1,2,5), 10^(1:4)))[1:10]) # 10 20 ... 5000 10000

## 16 replicates {want confidence!}
set.seed(1)
system.time(
    st.n <- sapply(setNames(n.s, paste0("n=",n.s)), 
                   function(n) replicate(16, do1(n)), simplify="array")
); attr(st.n, "version") <- R.version.string
## R 4.3.2 patched  (2024-01-25):
##    user  system elapsed
##  80.568  28.208 109.453
if(FALSE)
    saveRDS(st.n, "as.mat.D_st_R432p.rds")
## R-devel 2nd patch (by HT; + %in% .. by MMr)
 ##   user  system elapsed
 ## 29.250  10.617  40.121
if(FALSE)
    saveRDS(st.n, "as.mat.D_st_Rdev.rds")


stPlot <- function(st, ver = R.version.string, do.plot=TRUE) {
    stopifnot(is.array(st), length(dim(st)) == 3,
              is.character(R.version.string <- attr(st, "version")))
    <http://st.mn|st.mn> <- colMeans(st["user.self",,])
    n. <- as.integer(sub("^n=","", dimnames(st)[[3]]))
    if(do.plot)
        plot(n., <http://st.mn|st.mn>, type="b", log="xy", lwd=2, xlab = quote(n),  ylim =
c(1e-5, 5),
             main = "system.time(as.matrix.dist(n x n))[\"user.self\"]")
    else
        lines(n., <http://st.mn|st.mn>, type="b", lwd=2, lty=3, col="darkgreen")
    ## ~ linear in log-log (for non-small n)
    matlines(n.s, t(st["user.self",,]), col=adjustcolor(1:6, 1/2))
    mtext(R.version.string, adj=1, cex=3/4, line = if(do.plot) 0 else -1)
}

stPlot(st.n)

st.n432p <- readRDS("as.mat.D_st_R432p.rds")

stPlot(st.n432p, do.plot=FALSE)

<http://stRdev.mn|stRdev.mn> <- colMeans(st.n    ["user.self",,])
<http://stR432.mn|stR432.mn> <- colMeans(st.n432p["user.self",,])
cbind(<http://stR432.mn|stR432.mn>, <http://stRdev.mn|stRdev.mn>)

noquote(cbind(format(cbind(<http://stR432.mn|stR432.mn>, <http://stRdev.mn|stRdev.mn>) * 1e9 / n.s^1.65),
              q = sprintf("%2.1f%%", 100* <http://stR432.mn|stR432.mn> / <http://stRdev.mn|stRdev.mn>)))

##         <http://stR432.mn|stR432.mn> <http://stRdev.mn|stRdev.mn> q
## n=10    322.03826 249.85727 128.9%
## n=20    100.18911  95.17965 105.3%
## n=50     67.02674  49.15294 136.4%
## n=100    62.64840  43.07078 145.5%
## n=200    74.85862  29.94345 250.0%
## n=500    96.83496  61.62225 157.1%
## n=1000  154.97880  75.03498 206.5%
## n=2000  401.31635 107.92639 371.8%
## n=5000  580.69214 176.92733 328.2%
## n=10000 855.79971 234.89278 364.3%

```

OTOH, it's been a nice exercise to work to improve its R efficieny, and I do

Also, BTW, I did like the use

Here's some nice base R - only code for the analysis and I will attach the

    if(do.plot)
        plot(n.,

c(1e-5, 5),

text:
*[Bug 18655] Enhancements to `*wilcox` functions for large population sizes*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18655>

--- Comment #14 from Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) ---
Well, runtime is one thing...  correctness is  `Inf` times more important ;-)
With the latest patch (comment 10, attachment id 3239), I see

```
20 * dwilcox(0:12, 3,3) # giving     1 1 2 3 3 -2 -2 -1 0 1 0 0 0
                       ## instead of 1 1 2 3 3  3  3  2 1 1 0 0 0
```

.. a version of which is fortunately detected by `tests/d-p-q-r-tests.R`  where
 cumsum(dwilcox()) suddenly differs from pwilcox().

Optimistically, I assume this is just a small "typo" somewhere you'll find..
